Transcription for 1765041

Yn ymwneud â'r 11 o'r 1907, yw'r Mr. Charles Davies yn Bangor.
Yr ymwneud â'r Ddachym Diyaf, yw'r rhaid i'w ddweud ar y Rhaid Orgym.
A allwch chi ddysgu unrhyw ddau yn ôl?
Wel, gallwn ddweud...
Yn ogystal â chi?
Beth oedd yw'r ddau yma?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Yn ogystal â chi?
Pan oeddwch chi wedi dod i Canada?
13 o'r 1913.
13 o'r 1913.
A oeddwch chi wedi dod i Bangor?
Roeddwn i wedi dod i Bangor a'n dweud i roi ar y ddau yn ôl,
ond roeddwn i'n dweud i roi ar y ddau yn ôl,
os oeswn i ddod i'r ddau i'r ôl.
Why was this?
Well, Bangor, you know,
it took a knop a hole that time.
There wasn't much in here, you know,
and I couldn't find work in here,
and I didn't have no money.
I walked up and down the street, you know,
up to Walden, down here,
and I got a job at last.
Once I got a job, you know,
I wasn't too bad, you know.
But then you come to a place
and there was no soul, you know,
and there was now no money.
It was quite a thing.
Did you meet the Welsh people in this area?
Well, I...
Did you arrive?
I made my home at her home, you know.
Her father was Welsh,
and he got me a job for maybe a week.
I was working on the road there, you know,
from Walden then to Pwpysig,
until I got a job on the farm,
and then I was off.
Why did you come to Bangor?
Well, there was a fellow come from Wales.
I went to school with him.
A year before that.
And there were two of them come together,
I knew one,
and there were three of us.
A brother to this fellow I'm talking about,
and me and another fellow.
We all come together, three of us,
and we all come in here.
And the other two got a job, you know,
as soon as they came here,
and I didn't get a job.
So it was quite a thing anyway.
All strange.
And did you speak Welsh when you came here?
First of all?
Well, yes.
I got Welsh then.
And did you use it when you spoke to the other people in the area?
Oh, yes.
But I never...
I never, you know...
I couldn't read Welsh.
I never learned to read Welsh.
Never learned to read Welsh.
Because all English when I went to school, all English.
And I wasn't very smart at school, were you?
I only went to grade three.
At the highest event.
Yes.
And when you came out here then,
did you join in the Welsh activities in Bangor?
Did you go to the Welsh chapel here?
No, I...
I got a job in Walden, the next town up.
And well, in those days,
you didn't go nowhere, not like now.
There were no cars, nothing like that.
And hardly anything for you to go to.
Well, maybe there was a church in there, I know,
but there was no church in Walden.
So you were based more in Walden
and with the people here in Bangor,
into Welling and Grimlo.
You didn't see so much of it.
No, I didn't see it.
I never left home, you know,
where I worked for.
There was nothing for me to go to.
Nothing at all.
And when did you come back to Bangor?
Well, I don't know when.
When did we...
When we...
When we got the mail route.
Remember when we got the mail route in here?
I used to get my mail in Walden, you know.
And they got the mail route in Bangor here,
so I changed my mail in the middle of the Bangor,
because they used to come round the farm, you know,
the mail.
And I...
I was in the Wal for three years,
first World War.
So you were farming in there.
Oh, yes.
About three miles west of here,
between here and Walden.
I was on a farm from 1942 yesterday.
And did you find the farming here
similar to the farming at home in Wales?
Well, oh, yes, you know, in a way, you know.
But I used to work on the farm in Wales, you know,
but I wasn't...
My father wasn't farming in Wales.
My father wasn't farming.
He was a carpenter.
It was nine hours.
It was pretty hard up.
Nine hours.
Have you been back to Wales at all?
Well, yes, I was back there, you know,
when the war was on.
The second World War?
No, the first.
Yes, I...
I...
I went back there before I went over to France.
That was the rules, you know.
If you were from the whole country, you know.
Just give you a leave, you know,
about four or five days before you went over to France.
But you haven't been back since then.
No, I haven't been back since.
I got three sisters in the whole country.
Three sisters in the whole country.
And do you keep in touch with them?
Not very often.
Christmas time.
How many of them are in one family?
There were six boys of us,
the first six,
and the last three were three girls.
Nine of us, okay?
And the three girls are still alive.
And the other ones are well.
I've got two brothers killed in the war anyway.
That was in the whole country.
You don't sing in Welsh at all?
I'm no singer at all.
I'm not like the Welsh, you know.
Welsh are good singers, I know.
They do play for that.
Yes, I'm no singer at all.
I don't know, that's a lot of...

with Mrs T.T. Evans and Mrs T.E. Evans.
